item.title: Shop For DSL and Other Broadband Options Easily
item.description:
Frustrated with unreliable internet or sluggish dial-up? Now’s the perfect time to explore new DSL and broadband choices, thanks to an improved online tool. Shop for DSL, the innovative search engine, has been enhanced for user-friendliness and comprehensiveness. This real-time tool pinpoints broadband options specific to your location and neatly categorizes them for easy browsing. What makes this service stand out is its location-based approach. Broadband availability, particularly for DSL and Cable, hinges on your exact location...

The long-standing favored business internet connection for professionals has been the T1 line, recognized for its high reliability and consistent 1...

item.title: Data Caps: What They Are and How to Avoid Them
item.description:
By: John Shepler If you’re a frequent internet user, you’ve probably encountered data caps. This article explains these usage limits and how to navigate them. OK, What IS a Data Cap? A data cap restricts the amount of data transferred over a connection within a specific timeframe. Usually set monthly, these limits, measured in MB or GB, reset every 30 days. Activities like browsing, file transfers, and cloud backups consume this data...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/data-caps-what-they-are-and-how-to-avoid-them/

item.title: Can Satellite Be The Answer to Your Business Broadband Needs?
item.description:
By: John Shepler Are you feeling stuck because your business needs internet, even if it’s just local? Have you considered cable and DSL but found them unavailable in your area? Don’t worry, there’s a solution for getting high-speed internet, even in remote locations. The answer is satellite internet! Forget about expensive cable or fiber optic lines; this video explains why looking up is the way to go: Here are 10 important things to know about satellite internet for your business:..
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/can-satellite-be-the-answer-to-your-business-broadband-needs/

item.title: A Myriad of Business Broadband Options
item.description:
There are many choices for business broadband internet, even beyond options like DSL, 3G and 4G Wireless, Cable, Satellite, T1 lines, and Ethernet over Copper. These choices depend on if your business is small, medium, or large. However, no matter what they are physically made of (wireless, copper, coaxial cable, or fiber optic), they all boil down to two types: dedicated or shared broadband connections. Shared bandwidth options, like DSL, Cable, 3G & 4G Wireless and Satellite, are typically the cheapest...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/a-myriad-of-business-broadband-options/

item.title: HughesNet Special Deals on Satellite Broadband
item.description:
Living remotely doesn’t mean you have to be disconnected. Just like you get your TV via satellite, you can get internet access the same way. You’ll need a specialized dish that transmits and receives data, connect it to your power source and computer, and you’re online! HughesNet is one provider catering to both homes and businesses. Plans start at $59.99 per month, with download speeds up to 700 Kbps and upload speeds up to 128 Kbps, similar to many DSL or cellular broadband services...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/hughesnet-special-deals-on-satellite-broadband/

item.title: Yes, There IS Rural Broadband For Businesses
item.description:
Many people are excited about the economic stimulus plan’s promise of expanded rural broadband access. However, you might already be able to get the internet speeds your rural business needs. Most major internet providers have overlooked rural areas, not because rural businesses are less important, but because the cost of installing infrastructure like coaxial cables or fiber optic cables is difficult to recoup when there are fewer customers. This is why cable and DSL internet services are less common in the countryside...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/yes-there-is-rural-broadband-for-businesses/
